name: George Glazer Gallery
description: Unique antiquarian shop specializing in globes, maps, and prints.

name: Venetian Room
description:
This lavish room at NYC's French Embassy is a rare relic from the end of the Gilded Age. THIS GEM OF A ROOM at the French Embassy in New York City feels as though you've landed in a Venetian palace. Mirrored panels lining the walls reflect 18th-century European furnishings and beautiful artwork. Delicate porcelain flowers sprout within intricately entwined metal latticework. A floral timepiece crowns the milky white fireplace.

The embassy's Venetian Room is a rare surviving piece of New York's Gilded Age. The lavish display, which was created in 1906, was finished by famous architect Stanford White less than a year before he was murdered. White spent years traveling to Europe to hunt for inspiration and decor to turn his vision into a reality.

name: Albertine
description: Though its celestial ceiling is impressive, the true star is the vast collection of French books. bookstore in the French Consulate; One of the few remaining urban mansions of the Gilded Age, the Payne Whitney Mansion was commissioned in 1902 by Oliver Hazard Payne, for his nephew, Payne Whitney, on the occasion of his marriage to Helen Hay. Stanford White, of the prominent architectural firm McKim, Mead & White, designed the mansion in the style of a high Italian Renaissance palazzo. A jealous husband assassinated him before construction was completed in 1909.

name: The New York Society Library
description: New York's oldest and possibly grandest keeper of books.

name: Bohemian National Hall
description: Dvorak Hall - A small piece of the composer's New York home lives on in the center of Czech culture in Manhattan. The five-story building was designed by William C. Frohne in the Renaissance Revival style, and built in 1896. It is a rare survivor of the many social halls built in the nineteenth century for New York City's immigrant ethnic communities. In 2001, ownership of the Bohemian National Hall was transferred from the Bohemian Benevolent & Literary Association (BBLA) to the Czech Republic.

name: Urasenke Inc
description: Traditional Japanese tea ceremony school and cultural center.

name: Day & Meyer, Murray & Young Corp.
description: Storage warehouse of the rich and famous.

name: Grolier Club
description: The oldest bibliophilia club in America, with exhibitions on historic books and graphic arts. The Grolier Club is a private NYC club with galleries that are free and open to members of the public. The club was established in 1884, making it the oldest North American bibliophilic club in existence.

name: Society of Illustrators
description: Professional society and museum dedicated to the art of illustration.

name: Explorers Club
description: A treasure trove of artifacts, books, and artwork from the golden age of exploration.

name: Frick Madison
description: The Frick Collection is an art museum on Manhattan's Upper East Side that is home to Henry Clay Frick's collection of works. Frick began acquiring his personal collection in the 1800s after striking it big in the steel industry in Pennsylvania. The Frick is considered to have a small but extremely high quality and well-respected art collection, including pieces by Johannes Vermeer, Giovanni Bellini, and Rembrandt. Also home to a secret bowling alley.

name: Bemelmans Bar
description: The walls are decorated with whimsical murals painted by the creator of the Madeline franchise.

name: Park Avenue Armory
description: The Seventh Regiment Armory, or the Park Avenue Armory, is a National Guard armory building located on Park Avenue in Manhattan's Upper East Side neighborhood. The armory was designated a National Historic Landmark in 1986. The building is a Gothic Revival made of brick and stone, and was built in 1880.

name: Temple Emanu-El
description: Built in the Modern Romanesque-style popular in the late 1920s, Temple Emanu-El is one of the largest houses of worship in the world and the oldest Reform synagogue in New York City. The sanctuary features dazzling mosaics by noted muralist Hildreth Meière, an intricately painted ceiling, and towering stained glass windows.

name: Bernard Museum
description: Small museum housed within Temple Emanu-El focusing on Jewish art and artifacts.

name: Gracie Mansion Conservancy
description: The official residence of the Mayor of New York City, offering guided tours of this historic Federal-style mansion.

name: Adam Baumgold Fine Art
description: Shows work from comics and illustration art.

name: Neue Galerie New York
description: The Neue Galerie New York is an art gallery dedicated to German and Austrian art from the early 1900s. The Neue Galerie, translated from German as New Gallery, is one of the more recent museums to join NYC's Museum Mile on Manhattan's Fifth Avenue. The museum's best known piece in its collection is Klimt's painting Portrait of Adele Bloch-Bauer I.

name: Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum
description: The Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum is a design museum on NYC's Museum Mile. Cooper Hewitt is the only museum in the country that focuses on current day and historic design dating back more than 240 years. The former home of Andrew Carnegie, who described the 64-room mansion as modest and plain.

name: Di Donna
description: Gallery specializing in Old Master and Impressionist paintings.

name: James Cummins Bookseller
description: Rare and antiquarian bookstore specializing in fine books and manuscripts.

name: Mount Vernon Hotel Museum & Garden
description: The Mount Vernon Hotel Museum & Garden is a historic antebellum residential building near the East River that was once known as the Abigail Adams Smith Museum. The house is one of the last remaining buildings in Manhattan from the 17th century. It was meant for the Smith family, but ended up serving as a carriage house and stable instead.

name: House of the Redeemer
description: Townhouse now owned by Episcopal Church; has events & very affordable hotel.

name: The Jewish Museum
description: The Jewish Museum, located on Manhattan's Museum Mile, is the oldest Jewish museum in the world. The museum has more than 30,000 objects on display and runs multiple temporary exhibits throughout the year. Some of the better known artists with pieces housed in the collection are Marc Chagall, George Segal, Eleanor Antin, and Deborah Kass.

name: The American Irish Historical Society
description: Cultural institution dedicated to preserving Irish-American history and heritage.

name: Roosevelt House Public Policy Institute at Hunter College
description: Roosevelt House — the former double townhouse of Franklin, Eleanor and Sara Delano Roosevelt, and now owned by Hunter College — offers visitors a chance to get closer to a family as unique as the city they inhabited, and to explore the private spaces where some of the most iconic public policy of the 20th century was shaped. Tours for individuals on Saturday.

name: Institute for Studies on Latin American Art (ISLAA)
description: Research institute and gallery focusing on Latin American art and culture.

name: Carl Schurz Park
description: Waterfront park along the East River with stunning views and playgrounds.

name: Logos Bookstore
description: Religious bookstore specializing in Christian and theological texts.

name: Kitchen Arts & Letters, books on food and drink
description: Specialty bookstore devoted entirely to books about food and drink.

name: Schaller & Weber
description: Traditional German delicatessen and butcher shop since 1937.

name: Brandy's Piano Bar
description: Intimate piano bar featuring live music and cabaret performances.

name: Park Avenue Christian Church
description: Also used as a synagogue, this interfaith space serves multiple communities.

name: Institute for the Study of the Ancient World
description: NYU institute with exhibitions on ancient civilizations and cultures.

name: Tiny Doll House
description: Specialty shop selling miniature dollhouses and accessories.

name: Webster Library
description: Book Cellar used bookstore housed within the library.

name: John Finley Walk
description: Scenic esplanade along the East River with Manhattan skyline views.

name: Sotheby's New York
description: World-renowned auction house with regular exhibitions and sales.

name: Theosophy Hall Library
description: Library specializing in theosophical and spiritual texts.

name: St. Jean Baptiste Church
description: Historically catering to the French-Canadian population of the Upper East Side, this Catholic parish church was designed by an award-winning Italian architect influenced by the styles of Mannerism. Named a city landmark in 1969, the church is distinguished as one of the only ones in NYC with a dome.

name: ZITOMER
description: Zitomer is the ultimate version of a uniquely Manhattan phenomenon: The fancy, retro pharmacy where you can get your prescriptions filled but also easily drop $600 on velvet headbands. This wacky three-story storefront on Madison Avenue is a microcosm of everything that's simultaneously appealing and vexatious about the Upper East Side.

name: Creel and Gow
description: Boutique specializing in natural history curiosities, fossils, and taxidermy.

name: The Rockefeller University
description: Private research university known for biomedical sciences with beautiful campus architecture.

name: The Met Breuer
description: Look for 'Dwellings' - This miniature village stays behind in the Breuer Building, even as the museums around it come and go. THE BREUER BUILDING HAS BEEN home to three different museums since its construction in 1966: first the Whitney, which still owns the property, then it was a branch of the Met for four years, and now it's the temporary home of the Frick Collection.

name: Acquavella
description: High-end gallery specializing in Impressionist and Modern art.

name: Ukrainian Institute of America
description: Harry F. Sinclair House (now The Ukrainian Institute), an elaborate mansion with most of the original design intact.

name: Institute of Fine Arts, New York University
description: The James B. Duke House (today NYU Institute of Fine Arts) modeled after a French château, this was the home of Doris Duke, the richest girl in the world.

name: 86 St
description: Chuck Close murals located in the subway station.

name: Church of the Heavenly Rest
description: Episcopal church known for its beautiful Gothic Revival architecture.

name: La Casa Azul Bookstore
description: Bilingual bookstore specializing in Spanish and Latino literature.

name: The Poet's Den Theater
description: Intimate theater space featuring poetry readings and spoken word performances.

name: Ursus Books & Gallery
description: Rare books and prints specializing in art, architecture, and photography.

name: Gagosian
description: Major contemporary art gallery representing leading artists worldwide.

name: Castelli Gallery
description: Historic gallery that helped establish the careers of many major contemporary artists.

name: Herbert N. Straus House
description: Historic mansion with controversial recent history, originally built for the Straus family of Macy's fame.

name: Henderson Place
description: Historic row of Queen Anne-style houses from the 1880s.

name: The Pierre, A Taj Hotel, New York
description: Luxury hotel offering elegant afternoon tea service.

name: Roosevelt Island Visual Arts Association (RIVAA)
description: Community arts organization featuring local artists and exhibitions.

name: Blackwell House
description: Historic farmhouse on Roosevelt Island dating to 1796.

name: Lighthouse Park
description: Park on Roosevelt Island featuring ruins of a historic lighthouse.

name: El Museo del Barrio
description: Museum dedicated to Latino, Caribbean, and Latin American art and culture.

name: Graffiti Hall of Fame
description: For over 30 years the walls of this Harlem schoolyard have been a gallery of street art by Kings and better.

name: Saint Cecilia's Parish
description: Historic Catholic church in East Harlem.

name: Museum of the City of New York
description: Museum dedicated to the history, culture, and future of New York City.

name: New York Academy of Medicine
description: The New York Academy of Medicine, a neo-Romanesque building by York and Sawyer, was constructed 1925–1926, and is an Art Deco interpretation of the Romanesque style of architecture. The Academy is also home to one of the largest history of medicine libraries in the country, a library that has been open to the public for use since 1878.

name: Asphalt Green - Upper East Side campus
description: Mid-century modern fitness and community center with pools and sports facilities.

name: Czech Center New York
description: One of many social halls built in the nineteenth century for the city's immigrant ethnic communities, the Bohemian National Hall is a rare survivor that has both the charm of the old world in spaces like the Ballroom and the appeal of the modern through design elements introduced during its renovation. Today it is a vibrant cultural hub featuring art galleries, a Grand Ballroom, a rooftop terrace, cinema, library, and more.

name: Roosevelt Island Visitor Center Kiosk
description: Information center for Roosevelt Island visitors and tourists.

name: Cornell Tech
description: Graduate school campus known for innovative technology education and modern architecture.

name: Smallpox Memorial Hospital
description: A crumbling hospital from the 1850s on Roosevelt Island.

name: Wildlife Freedom Foundation
description: Organization dedicated to wildlife conservation and education.

name: Franklin D. Roosevelt Four Freedoms State Park
description: Memorial park designed by Louis Kahn honoring FDR's Four Freedoms speech.

name: Saint Nicholas Russian Orthodox Cathedral
description: Beautiful Russian Orthodox cathedral with traditional onion domes.

name: Cultural Services of the French Embassy
description: The Payne Whitney House (today Cultural Services, Embassy of France) where a statue by the teenage Michelangelo was rediscovered in the 1990s.

name: Otto H. Kahn House
description: The home of Otto Kahn one of the most famous bon vivant of the 1920s who may have been the inspiration for Mr. Monopoly.

name: Tzu Chi Center 慈濟大愛人文中心
description: The Tzu Chi Center for Compassionate Relief honors the history of global missions of humanitarianism and its trajectory into the 21st century. The Buddhist Tzu Chi Foundation has also played a major role in emergency response and relief work for minority groups in New York City for the past 33 years.

name: AS/COA New York | Americas Society/Council of the Americas
description: Organization promoting understanding of the Western Hemisphere through cultural programs.

name: The Africa Center
description: Cultural institution dedicated to African art, culture, and contemporary issues.

name: Christ Church NYC
description: Episcopal church known for its community outreach and beautiful architecture.
